s0001: Confucius was born in Zouyi village, Changping township of Lu.
s0002: His ancestors were from Song, named Kong Fangshu.
s0003: Fangshu fathered Bo Xia, Bo Xia fathered Shu Liang He.
s0004: He mated with a Yan family woman out of wedlock and gave birth to Confucius, having prayed at Ni Hill to obtain Confucius.
s0005: Confucius was born in the twenty-second year of Duke Xiang of Lu.
s0006: He was born with a sunken fontanelle on top of his head, so he was named Qiu accordingly.
s0007: His courtesy name was Zhong Ni, surname Kong.
s0008: Qiu was born and Shu Liang He died, buried at Fang Mountain.
s0009: Fang Mountain is east of Lu, so Confucius doubted the location of his father's grave, because his mother kept it secret.
s0010: When Confucius was a child at play, he would always arrange the sacrificial stands and assume ritual postures.
s0011: When Confucius's mother died, he held the funeral at Wufu crossroads, showing his caution.
s0012: A Zou person, the mother of Ran You's father, informed Confucius of his father's grave, then he went and joined the burial at Fang.
s0013: Confucius was in mourning attire when the Ji family feasted the scholars, and Confucius went along.
s0014: Yang Hu rebuked him saying: 'The Ji family feasts the scholars, not daring to feast you.'
s0016: At age seventeen, Lu minister Meng Xi Zi was ill and near death, admonishing his heir Yi Zi saying: 'Kong Qiu is a descendant of sages, extinguished in Song.
s0017: His ancestor Fu Fu He first had Song but yielded to Li Gong.
s0018: And Zheng Kao Fu assisted Dai, Wu, and Xuan Gong, three summons becoming increasingly respectful, hence the ding inscription says: "One summons and bent, two summons and bowed, three summons and prostrated, following the wall and running, none dare insult me.
s0019: Rice here, gruel here, to fill my mouth."'
s0021: I have heard that descendants of sages, though not contemporary, must have achievers.
s0022: Now Kong Qiu is young and fond of ritual, is he an achiever?
s0023: If I die, you must take him as teacher.'
s0024: When Xi Zi died, Yi Zi and Lu man Nan Gong Jing Shu went to study ritual with him.
s0025: This year, Ji Wu Zi died, and Ping Zi succeeded him.
s0027: When grown, he once served as Ji family accountant, measuring quantities fairly;
s0028: once served as keeper of stores and increased the livestock.
s0029: From this he became Director of Works.
s0030: Then he left Lu, was rejected in Qi, driven out of Song and Wei, besieged between Chen and Cai, then returned to Lu.
s0031: Confucius was nine chi six cun tall, people all called him 'tall man' and considered him unusual.
s0032: Lu again treated him well, so he returned to Lu.
s0033: Lu's Nan Gong Jing Shu spoke to the Lu lord saying: 'Please go with Confucius to Zhou.'
s0034: The Lu lord gave him one chariot, two horses, one attendant, went to Zhou to inquire about ritual, reportedly meeting Lao Zi.
s0035: When leaving, Lao Zi saw him off saying: 'I have heard that the wealthy and noble send people off with wealth, benevolent people send people off with words.
s0036: I cannot be wealthy and noble, I secretly bear the title of benevolent person, send you off with words, saying: "Those who are clever and deeply perceptive yet close to death are those who like to criticize others.
s0037: Those who are broadly argumentative and expansive endanger themselves are those who expose others' faults.
s0038: As a son, do not consider yourself important; as a minister, do not consider yourself important."'
s0039: Confucius returned from Zhou to Lu, and disciples gradually increased.
s0040: At this time, Jin Ping Gong was licentious, the six ministers monopolized power, attacking eastern feudal lords;
s0041: Chu Ling Wang's troops were strong, trampling the central states;
s0042: Qi was large and close to Lu.
s0043: Lu was small and weak, attaching to Chu angered Jin;
s0044: attaching to Jin brought Chu to attack;
s0045: not preparing for Qi brought Qi troops to invade Lu.
s0046: In Duke Zhao of Lu's twentieth year, Confucius was about thirty years old.
s0047: Qi Jing Gong and Yan Ying came to Lu, Jing Gong asked Confucius: 'In the past, Qin Mu Gong's state was small and in a remote place, how did he become hegemon?'
s0048: He replied: 'Qin, though the state was small, its ambitions were great;
s0049: though the place was remote, its conduct was upright.
s0050: He employed the worthy and able, listened to straight words, united the Western Rong, cultivated virtue and righteousness, served the king respectfully, aided the weak, attacked the violent - this is how he became hegemon.'
s0051: 景公說，厚禮留孔子，孔子固辭不受，歸魯。
s0052: 孔子年三十五，而季平子與郈昭伯以鬪雞故得罪魯昭公，昭公率師擊平子，平子與孟孫氏、叔孫氏三家共攻昭公，昭公師敗，奔於齊，齊處昭公乾侯。
s0053: 其後季平子卒，季桓子嗣位。
s0054: 桓子嬖臣曰仲梁懷，與陽虎有隙。
s0055: 陽虎欲逐懷，公山不狃止之。
s0056: 其明年，懷益驕，陽虎執懷。
s0057: 桓子怒，陽虎因囚桓子，與盟而釋之。
s0059: 季氏亦僭於公室，陪臣執國政，是以魯自大夫以下皆僭離於正道。
s0060: 故孔子不仕，退而修詩書禮樂，弟子彌眾，至自遠方，莫不受業焉。
